data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Humans considered as a group or in indefinite numbers. Often treated as a plural of person, especially in compounds.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: People were dancing in the street. I met all sorts of people. This book is not intended for laypeople.

data.text: The mass of ordinary persons; the populace. Used with the.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A body of persons living in the same country under one national government; a nationality.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The citizens of a political unit, such as a nation or state; the electorate. Used with the.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A body of persons sharing a common religion, culture, or language.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Persons with regard to their residence, class, profession, or group.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Persons subordinate to or loyal to a ruler, superior, or employer.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: The manager would like to introduce you to our people in the regional office.
